page.title: 08The Railway
page.content: Penkridge station was built in the 1870' by the London and North Western Railway. It has a building which the station master lived in and a small booking office and toilets. The Up platform is about 90 feet long and the Down platform has a wooden shelter. The footbridge is of the newer type, built because the trains were too fast for the crossing. Down the line is a goods shed where all the wares used to come in by train into Penkridge. Up the line is a junction where the Coal Board line joins. Here there is a signal box which controls the movement of trains. The LMS took over the line in 1923 until 1948 when British Rail took it over. The last man to live in the station was in 1975, since then it has been vandalised. In 1984 the Manpower Services Commission cleaned it up.
